page.title: 09Patricroft - 19C Ind. area
page.content: This is an area of mixed housing and industry, mainly in decline except for engineering works and a large Royal Ordnance factory. It developed rapidly in 1840-1850 using the Bridgewater canal as its main transport link. James Naysmyth, of steam hammer fame, established his works here in 1840-1850. Most people both lived and worked in the area. Long Victorian terraces of red brick houses are now being replaced by modern terraces of local authority housing. It is bounded on the south side by the Manchester Ship Canal. Many industries, including The Patricroft Engine Sheds of British Rail, have closed and unemployment in the area is high. The area used to have a high area of industrial pollution, but since the Clean Air Acts the area is cleaner.
